reviews.review_msg: I have never given a teacher a review I am happy he connected with his class tried his best to make Hegel and Marx engaging to us I appreciate his concern for the world teachers like him will be missed years to come came late for class a lot he never bashed me took time to help me and understand my situation man Gary thank you for being great

tough class with big assignments, but amazing prof who really knows his stuff. had him for two upper level sociology classes this semester. he is kind and approachable and clearly an expert in his field. there is no better way to read marx's capital than under gary's guidance! his study notes guidebook is great.

SFU is lucky to have a professor like him who should very well be working somewhere much more prestigious. Lecture's are not 'dry' as many have said, you just need to come engaged and awake. The style of teaching is akin to much higher level education. It's hard but so, SO worth it, and to have a reference from him would be like striking gold.

Love this prof, he is always helpful and makes it easy to understand concepts, he is down to spend a long time emailing you and talking to you before or after class (or office hours) just for you to better understand concepts.

He's an excellent professor if sociology truly interests you and especially if you want to get a good theoretical background on neoliberalism, capitalism and Marxism. He's an incredibly kind person and I really enjoyed his dry humour! Going to lecture isn't mandatory but it will really help you when you write your paper. Take him!!!

Prof Teeple was kind but honestly I still have no idea what the class was about. We had 2 papers, very little criteria was given for them. They were both based on outside readings so really no need to go to class unless you want to. He doesn't take attendance. No exams, entire grade based on the 2 papers. Super chill prof if you don't mind writing

SA 351 is one of the best classes I have taken at SFU. Gary was helpful, but unfortunately I found him to be a bit disorganized when it comes to handing back work and replying to emails. You should be aware that the final paper is worth 50% and the length is around 20 pages, so it's well worth to prepare in advance. This class was very inspiring !

Fantastic. 10/10. Hard course and he is particular in what he's looking for, but he is so accessible via email and will take the time to re-explain concepts and support your research for larger projects. Ask questions! He will answer, and he will answer quickly. Don't be intimidated by the coursework and let him know where you're at.

The basic layout of the class is very simple. The lectures are heavy but they are also very informative and you genuinely learn from them. But the best part is that he actually you some of the basics when it comes to critical thinking unlike most sociology classes. I think that everyone should his class at least for that.

For first year students who want a take on the history of Canadian political economy, take this course while you can before he retires. From the opeming lecture it was a tour-de-force and will readily dispel misconception of both conservative and politically correct versions of history that the Canadian state programmed you with in high school.

Gary expertly explains how Capital Vol. 1 is a paradigm shift in how to perceive the world. You get out of it what you put in, however. He is very accessible and genuinely cares about both the subject and your comprehension of it. Its not for the weak or for ideologues. 351 is for the true scholar.

Do not take this course as an elective! Gary is a very nice, knowledgeable prof, however, the content of this course was so weird and abstract. I could not understand a single reading! Don't take this course unless you're passionate about getting super deep into technology and capitalism. Also only 2 papers, 1 worth 40%, the other 50%...

Gary's a knowledgable and kind man. He lectures straight through and it's mostly on his own theories (poli-econ based), which was a disappointing for a class on classical theory. Though he can say some interesting things, but he repeats himself A LOT, so it's not necessary to go to all classes. Bonus- You can read/write about whatever you want!

Gary is a very reasonable professor. His lectures can be boring (sorry if you're reading this Gary). But, his grading is so reasonable and it is not hard to do well if you put in effort. Gary understands that different students have different learning levels and he really caters to that.
He seems to be a nice prof and his lectures are very dry. But if you want to do well in the class, it's incredibly hard to get an A. Holy man is this prof tough like watch out Jesus man.

I appreciate any professor who wants their students to succeed. Gary is this way. As well, he is passionate about his work, a fair marker, and an engaging lecturer. I recommend Gary to any student based on his fairness, kindness, and intellect.
Gary is awesome! He genuinely cares about sharing ideas with students. He genuinely wants everyone to do well, and is a very kind person.

Really caring prof, lectures are interesting but not mandatory. No textbook, he instead suggests a list of readings for each week and you can pick which one to do study notes on. Critical book review and final paper worth 40% and 50% respectively, so get ready to write. Only take the class if you have a really interest in the subject.

75 questions about Capital assignment, was the most challenging thing I had to do in my undergrad and everyone in the class did poorly on it. His grading for it also made no sense, wish I had talked to others in the class so we could challenge him on it. Other than that he is very good at explaining concepts. 20 page final paper.

Lectures are dry, in my opinion. He seems genuinely caring about the subject and making sure students get a good grade. I was behind on work and he allowed me to hand it in, so I received a good grade in the end.

Gary is one of a kind. His lectures aren't mandatory, but we attend anyway because of how engaging he is. This is a man of knowledge and experience. He has such a cool way about him too, a sense of ease. He explains the most complex of systems in concise and easy to understand terms- true intelligence. Super approachable and caring. Recommend!
lectures arent mandatory but recommended. hes so interesting and knowledgeable
Amazingly insightful, passionate about his topic, clear and responsive. It really helps if you have an interest in the course topic - you'll garner a lot more from the class than the credits.

Really interesting course - not a ton of room for discussion though Gary is fairly encouraging. Very knowledgeable and approachable. Quite a bit of reading, as weekly study notes are required throughout the semester. Final paper is open-ended and worth a lot. Good writing skills are a must.

Loved the prof, not the subject. I am not a fan of reading Marx. I like listening Teeple talk about him more :). However, I found that not having a ppt to look at made the class quite dry. I wish we were allowed to discuss Marx rather than just sit and listen.

Gary is very interested in the subject and he basically lectures the whole four hours. There are no ppt, so it may be hard to follow. Basically you have a term essay (40%), final essay (50%), and study notes (10%). It wasn't mandatory to attend his class because the essays that you will be writing is based off from the selection of books he chose

Be careful reading some of these comments. They are vague and rambling. Using words like not valid (invalid?), not sound (unsound?), biased, illogical, etc., in a sentence does not turn your opinion into an argument.  If you want to be an academic, then learn what a premise, inference and conclusion actually is.

Be careful learning Gary's material. His premises are not valid and his conclusions are not sound. His presentation and style is good, but please pay attention and you will find that he reaches conclusions that are illogical and biased. If you want to be an academic, then it is difficult to digest everything Gary feeds you.

Utter Genius.  Tremendous ability to communicate abstract thought to ants. Inspired me to pursue academia. Has so many sources backing his Marxism that he's near impossible to refute.  Interested in helping his students' intellectual development. It saddens me to think of future Soc students when he retires.  Gary is irreplaceable.  Best prof ever.

Really nice, easygoing guy. I like the way he has us choose our own readings from the library. Yes, some statements he makes in 325 are difficult to credit, but he tells you from the beginning that the lectures he presents are an argument, not "the truth." I learned a lot from these classes and would take another class with him.

He knows a lot about the subject and was interesting. I didn't like that there was no text and instead journal articles or books that we had to choose from the list, find, and read each week and do study notes on. Also, there was no final so as long as you were there for enough classes to be able to write the two essays it seemed pointless for me.

Great introductory course to volume 1 of Capital. 2 papers and chapter questions are requirements. He gives you notes and summary of all chapters in the book so you don't have to read it and in lectures he answers the chapter questions so you just copy them. 1 midterm paper (10 pages) and final paper (15 pages) and your good! Nicest prof i've had

Be careful of taking this class. His teachings are insidiously totalitarian: he presents only one view; he does not encourage debate; his marking is arbitrary; and there is a high level of student apathy in the class- only half the students ever attended his lectures.

Genuinely interested in the intellectual growth of his students. Incredibly kind, humble and engaging. He has inspired me to continue to engage with the dominant discourse in a critical way. As well, his concepts have allowed me to find meaning by connecting to the infinite subjectivity of the human spirit. Also, he has lovely shoes.

Do not take this class if you're interested in expanding your mind beyond marxists theories. He does not present a balance approach, nor does he offer credible support for the maxist theories he holds. I felt sorry for the people in my class who were being brainwashed to think in such a narrow view. Teeple is bitter of politics, and it shows.

I don't see all the hype that other students have experienced with Teeps. I finished an assignment a week before submission, and I met with him to review the thesis, and general idea, yet he gave me a B-. He seems stickler, and keeps students 5 minutes after each class. I ended up with a B+ thankfully, but I didn't enjoy his class.

Nice guy. Knows Capital in and out, helps you understand it. He wears his bias on his sleeve though.  He definitely made some dubious claims coloured by this bias. Though having a marxist teach you marx makes sense.  Alternative viewpoint = always good.   Recommend the class, as Capital is an extraordinary work and Teeple is an expert and is fair.

I took all his courses (SA250,322,362,351,416). Professor Teeple is the embodiment of an enlightened thinker, humanist, and critical theorist. He is a world renown Marx (his supervisors were Tom Bottomore and David McLellan at Sussex) and he has worked hard all his life. Take any class with him!!
An outstanding professor. Gary's lectures are stimulating and his critique of social democracy is profound.

one of the best profs i've had. made my unpleasent last semester less unpleaseant...really helps you understand Marx and his analysis of captialism in a way no other course would.now i'm ready to start a revolution

Marx's CApital is the whole focus of the course. Teeple is very helpful and familiar with the text. This course should be a requirement for all students, and reading the text of Capital is very helpful to understand many currents in the modern capitalist system.
BEST PROF EVER!
enlightening

excellent prof!! He sure knows his stuff, and also his voice is very soothing which can lead to sleepiness(IF YOU ARE TIRED).. but other than that great professor. Pretty fair in markings. He reminds me of paul newman..har har!

Excellent professor. He lectures in an articulate, clear, and engaging way. He explains complex ideas and concepts in simple and understandable manner. I will definately try and get into another class that he is teaching.

Very good professor.  Very knowledgeable.  Committed to social change.  Cares about students.  Flexible requirements, does not want to exploit you with tons of work, and actually teaches you important stuff.  If you haven't had a class with him... take one.
a great professor, very helpful and gives clear instructions to assignments.  the course was a little dull, however the content was extremely engaging.  Dr. Teeple knows the topic very well.

in his sociology of art course, mr teeple spent much time expounding upon his antiquated belief that european culture is vastly superior to (and he specified) first nations art forms, east indian and middle eastern cultures and religions, among others.
The best prof I Have had so far!

Very knowledgeable and articulate. Also very flexible as far as due dates go. Will definitely issue a challenge and make you work for your grade. If you still have optimistic delusions about the "free" market, this class is for you.
content was very dry, love the no exam policies, but assignments were difficult
clear lectures, but depressing ideas taught-anti relgion, with pessimism
Lectures are one-sided anti-capitalist tirades. Love the no-exam policy.
Very articulate, helpful, and a  fair marker!
